B000002KIK|4.0|I have read many reviews which regard this Sabbath album as a downer, and can't understand why. True, it marked the end of an era for Ozzy, but it holds up after all these years as a fitting closer. I heard this album back in 1978 while in Junior High, then did not hear it again until I bought the CD in 1993. I wondered if I would like it after forgetting so many songs from it. It turns out, I liked it even better as I got older and my tastes grew. The band transcended the typical cliches of 70's heavy rock, adding textures and chord changes that were inventive. It never mattered how heavy Sabbath got, they always stayed rooted in melody - perhaps Ozzy's singing style can account for this. The riffs were always balanced against a strong melody. I loved the synth and piano textures in here, as well as the slightly jazzy guitar approach on &quot;Air Dance&quot;. The title track is heavy and dark but at the same time, almost cheery in a major-chord way. The same can be said for &quot;It's a Hard Road&quot;. The only clunker to my ears is the closing track, &quot;Swinging the Chain&quot;. The vocals are not up to Ozzy's standards ( the track is not sung by him), and musically it is weak. All in all, a strong and varied album that shows a band not treading water at the end of an era.
B00005OM4N|5.0|Overall, I was pleasntly surprised by this album. I admit that I'm a Britney fan 110% of the way, but I hadn't seen to many people that actually liked &quot;I'm A Slave 4 U&quot; which didn't make me feel that this album would be too big. Now, &quot;Britney&quot; does show a growth spurt in Ms. Spears, maybe not a big one though. Her sound hasn't really matured except for on a few occasional songs. She still sings her heart out on the topic of love, but like &quot;Oops!' is beginning to demand more respect then what we saw on &quot;Baby...&quot;.  She's becoming a woman, admist catchy tunes and sometimes childish lyrics. I HIGHLY suggest that everyone goes and purchases this album now because you WON'T be dissapointed at all. Here's a song-by-song review:<br />1.I'm A Slave 4 U-This is a completely new sound for Britney, and I feel that it's one of her best songs so far. I feel the need to get up and dance every time I hear this song. The chorus flows SOOOOOO well that it's scary, but this song lacks an actual formula, and if anything that just makes it even better. Plus, the dance break in the middle is so tight. 5/5<br />2.Overprotected-Actually, this is a surprisingly good song. At times you get an electronica feel, and the &quot;I need love, time, space&quot; part of the song sounds great. The breakdown where she semi-raps is a fine addition to this already perfect song. 5/5<br />3.Lonely-Without a doubt, this is the best song on the album. The chorus is SOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOO unbelievably addictive that it's not even funny. I kinda get a feel of &quot;What U See (What U Get)&quot; from &quot;Oops!&quot; when I listen to this song in the sense that it's such a powerful song, probably the most powerful song on this entire album. I'm not even doing justice to this song...you need to listen to this song and you WILL agree. Shoot, I've already listened to this song about 50 times. 5/5 (it's worth more though)<br />4. I'm Not A Girl, Not Yet A Woman-The only ballad onthe entire album. Truthfully, it's a good song, but like her ballads from the other previous albums it's nothing too powerful. This sounds alot like &quot;From The Bottom Of My Broken Heart&quot; since her ballads don't seem to mature with her. It sucks that she doesn't have a powerhouse voice, but this song is still beautiful and will touch you. 3/5<br />5.Boys-Sounds alot like &quot;I'm A Slave 4 U&quot; at times. She speaks the verses, which gets kinda annoying. The background vocals on the entire song are unique but occasionally don't blend well with Britney's voice. It's a bit of a sexually-suggestive song at times, but the chorus is pretty cathy though. 4/5<br />6.Anticpating-This song kinda gives the impression of the earlier Michael Jackson songs. Basically, she sings about going to the club dancing, and I really enjoy this song. This reminds me of a few songs off &quot;Baby...&quot; but to a new level. She's done well with this song...I'm very pleased. 5/5<br />7.I Love Rock 'N' Roll-Britney covers a song on every album, and decided on the Joan Jett classic this time. Truthfully, it's not as good as &quot;(I Can't Get No) Satisfaction&quot;, but she gets credit because this is a complete rock song, and doesn't show one bit of pop. Not the best song on the album, but fairly good. 4/5<br />8.Cinderella-The lyrics get cheesy at times, and the chorus is pretty good...the verses get your attention though. It's an OK song, and I still like it. Not one of Britney's best, but it's still one that you want to put on repeat in your stereo. 4/5<br />9.Let Me Be-I don't really know how to describe this song. I like it, and it's pretty original for Ms. Spears. I get a latin feel at times, but it adds to this already amazing song. 5/5<br />10.Bombastic Love-Like &quot;Let Me Be&quot; this is a pretty original song for Britney. Lyrics are cheesy here also occasionally, but it's OK. Not a bad song, but not her best either. There's an opera solo in the middle of the song, which sounds alot like &quot;Most Girls&quot; by Pink. But the opera section is th ebest part of the song...something new for her that I like. 4/5<br />11.That's Where You Take Me-Like &quot;Anticipating&quot; this is song gives you a childish feeling...I like the sound though which she pulls off very well. Well done, Britney. 5/5<br />12.What It's Like To Be Me-This is a standout song, and one of the best on the album. Justin, her boyfriend, wrote it and he provides the background vocals for her. I think this is the second best song on the album. The beat is AMAZING, and Britney's and Justin's voices blend well together. Like &quot;Lonely&quot; I can't even do this song justice. Justin b-boxes twice during the song, and actually the second time he does is at the end of the song, and it sounds brilliant. I get a kind of hip-hop feel from this song, and it's just TERRIFIC!! 5/5 (once again, it's worth more than that)<br />OVERALL GRADE:4.5/5
B00005OM4N|5.0|All the songs in the album are great!!!!!<BR>It's worth to spend money on!<BR>Belive me.

B00002MZ4W|5.0|Apple's 1996 release Tidal offered some interesting alternative music and smokey alto vocal turns, but the record was uneven and had only one real &quot;hit&quot; song, Criminal. What's criminal, however, is how her far superior follow-up, When the Pawn... was mostly ignored by radio. Songs Limp, Fast As You Can, and Paper Bag showcase a mature singer/songwriter who knows how to create a hook both musically and metaphorically.<br />Highlights of the album include the lyrics of Paper Bag, where Apple laments: &quot;I've got to fold cause these hands are too shaky to hold; hunger hurts but starving works when it comes to love.&quot;<br />Such lyrical wizardly repeats throughout the consistent album, which ends with the heartbreaking &quot;I know.&quot; When the Pawn... may not feature Fiona Apple acting sexy and nymph-like like in her video for Criminal, but it does feature a vastly improved artist.

6304765789|5.0|What kind of birthday gift do you get for a guy who has everything? How about something he cannot buy?  Like a renewed appreciation for things he has. Not just material things, but his personal relationships--and even his life itself.  <BR>Michael Douglas stars as Nicholas Van Orton, a divorced wealthy businessman who has acquired all the material wealth one could ever want, but something is lacking. <BR>Enter The Game. <BR>It is Nicholas's 48th birthday and his rebellious brother, played by Sean Penn, gives as a gift an invitation to play The Game.<BR>Nicholas is not informed of the rules of said game or even when it will start.  He is told that it is sort of like a vacation only you don't go to it--it comes to you. <BR>He is thrown into a series of events which at the beginning he is slightly amused. But the stakes increase and when his world is so unpredictable and turned upside down and he thinks he's lost everything, he is convinced that this is no longer a game. It becomes a struggle for his very life. <BR>The ending is emotionally moving and it makes the viewer think about what is really important in life.  <BR>Buy it. Rent it. B00005JKHP|5.0|It's amazing.  Robert Wise and company have removed everything bad about this film.  The pacing is better and stronger.  The new visual effects are amazing and the old ones have been tidied.  The best change, in my opinion, was removing that honk-honk-honk &quot;red alert&quot; effect and that terrible computer voice -- the film's now less cluttered and flows much, much better.  There are a couple of nits to pick -- for example, in the new external shots, the ship's running lights don't flash -- but that's just to please the hardcore Trekkie nitpickers.   Just an incredible rework of a bad film into a near-classic.
B00005O5CM|5.0|This is an endearing and wonderful film that maximizes a great cast and an excellent screenplay.  I can hardly believe the negative reviews this film elicited in its cinema run.  The plot is very fluid and continuous.  There is an occasional weak moment (i.e., Reese Witherspoon dressed as a pink Playboy Bunny for an alleged costume party.)  But who cares?  Even the weak moments are fun!<BR>  <BR>   Witherspoon's heroine, Elle Woods, is a warm and extroverted young woman madly in love with a pompous Harvard law student who breaks up with her because she is not conservative and serious enough to fulfil his political aspirations.  Loyal Elle enrolls at Harvard (despite her glamorous fashion interests, she is quite intelligent) determined to prove she can cut it in Pompous Boyfriend's world. Despite several challenges (cutthroat instructors, hostile professional students who don't take her seriously) Elle does not give up her candor, courtesy, or optimism.  She moves on to prove her worth through actions, sometimes intuitive and impulsive, but on the mark nonetheless. <br />  I think the underlying message in this film is not to discriminate against people because they are &quot;different&quot; than what you stereotype people to be.  Why couldn't a savvy party girl also be a successful attorney?  This is the sort of prejudice women in our country have been fighting for years.<br />  With wit, class, and charm &quot;Legally Blonde&quot; provides all that it promises: eye candy, comedy, and romantic fun. Classic entertainment!!!A definite keeper!!!

B00003CXA4|3.0|Richard Attenborough's Gandhi is a loving look at the life of one the biggest figures of the 20th century.  Tracing his life from a young man to his final days as the spiritual leader of India, Mr. Attenborough leaves no stone unturned.  That's the film's biggest problem, it is long and exhaustive and drags in one too many places.  Ben Kingsley is brilliant in the lead role.  His transformation from a strong-headed young lawyer to the understanding leader of non-violent resistance is remarkable.  Mr. Kingsley won a well-deserved Oscar (though Paul Newman was equally deserving for his role in The Verdict that year) for the role.  The film is also quite beautiful to look at as Mr. Attenborough captures the mysticism of India.  If one can fight through the over three hours of film, you will have seen a great performance and beautiful vistas.  The film predictably swept through the 1982 Oscars (the academy loves factual epics), winning Best Picture, Best Director, as mentioned Best Actor and five other awards.
B000002L73|5.0|If you would ask me to pick the worst Ramones albums, the choice would be easy : 'End of the Century', 'Subterranean Jungle' and 'Pleasant Dreams'. Not that any of these albums are bad, but they don't cut it as much as all their other CDs. 'Too Tough To Die' has everything you expect from a Ramones album and more. The production is outstanding and the Ramones never sounded better than this. Songs like 'Too Tough To Die', 'Daytime Dilemma', 'Endless Vacation' or even 'Wart Hog' kick you in the guts and make you come back for more. Joey's contributions like 'No Go', 'Howling at the Moon' or 'Chasing the Night' are fantastic rock songs and prove, that he was just as much a 'Rock'n'Roller' than a 'Punk Rocker'. This album will make you go back to Amazon.com and order the remaining Ramones albums !

B000025XDU|5.0|If you grew up in the USA, you probably did not hear too much of Status Quo after their early hit in the sixties 'Pictures of Matchstick Men'. Generally, you can group their albums into three stages : Their 'Early years' which ended with their 'Dog of two heads' album - their 'Great year' which started with 'Piledriver' and ended with 'Back to Back' and then there are the 'It's all downhill from here' years which started with the 'In the Army Now' album and just won't end ! If you only want three Status Quo albums, buy their 1976 'Live' double CD, the 1979 'Whatever you Want' album (if you are lucky, you might find the 'Whatever you Want / Just Supposin' ' CD which unfortunately does not include the fantastic 'High Flyer' that was released on vinyl only) and buy this album - 1973's 'Hello !'. During this time period, Quo were on top of the world, or at least on top of Europe. They finally found their niche with 'Piledriver' and with this album they mastered their science. 'Roll over lay down' gets things started and is followed by `Claudie', which is one of Francis Rossi's finest moments. 'Reason for Living' is a hopping little Quo piece and 'Blue Eyed Lady' must be the most underrated Quo track ever. It shows, that these guys could really play ! Side two of the original vinyl album starts with THE Quo classic: 'Caroline'. 'Softer Ride' keeps on rocking' and the most quiet part of this album is 'And it's better now'. And then comes the 9 minute boogie explosion of 'Forty-Five Hundred Times' - I guarantee, these are some of the best 9 minutes you have heard from any rock group. If you still have some money left after buying the three albums mentioned above, get the 1974 release 'Quo' which is their hardest album ever (thanks to the major contribution of founding member and bass player Alan Lancaster) - but 'Hello' presents Status Quo at their best !
0393312836|5.0|I have read this book several times, and read many of the reviews posted here. Many wrote that Burgess' invented slang was difficult at first, or slowed the book down. I couldn't disagree more. <BR>Burgess' ear for patterns of speech, colloquialism and his seemingly instinctive choices for slang are uncanny, if not absolutely brilliant. How many writers can invent a language? And do it in such a readable way, that meshes perfectly with the timeframe and intention of the story?<BR>Add to this that he has created empathetic characters, a perfect linear narrative, and an incredible social commentary that has every bit of relevance now as it did when it was written. What is the result?<BR>...A truly great work, which will be read and will provoke thought long after this reviewer and the likes of amazon.com have perished. <BR>Sorry to be so dramatic, but few books fly at this lofty altitude of excellence.

B00000DCHD|4.0|Without a doubt, \\"The Stranger\\" was a breakthrough album for Billy Joel as it produced several Top-40 singles and, at the same time, it validated his credentials as a pop artist. Having enjoyed considerable success with this album, it would've been easy for Joel to stay the course and follow-up with another album that took the same musical approach. If he did, it would undoubtedly be successful but it would also be formulaic and lackluster too. Fortunately, this didn't happen. <BR> <BR>On \\"52nd Street\\", Joel rises to the occasion by pushing his creative talents to a higher level by blending up-tempo pop with mainstream jazz--with great results no less! Although \\"52nd Street\\" didn't produce as many hit singles as \\"The Stranger\\", it's still a fine album and it's one that every Billy Joel fan will want to own. Here's a summary and an evaluation of each song on the album: <br />Big Shot: An in-your-face rocker that seethes with anger and ridicule. Grade: A+<br />Honesty: While \\"Big Shot\\" is full of scorn, \\"Honesty\\" has an air of incredulity and cynicism to it. Released as a single, \\"Honesty\\" received a lot of airplay on adult contemporary stations and is still a playlist favorite. However, it's not one of my favorites as it's a bit too slow. Grade: C-<br />My Life: A nice up-tempo song that features Chicago's Peter Cetera and Donnie \\"No Talent\\" Dacus on background vocals. This was a Top-10 hit back in 1978 and it still gets a fair amount of airplay even today. A good song but it's beginning to sound a bit jaded. Grade: B<br />Zanzibar: One of my favorites! Nice jazz-pop number that features trumpeter Freddie Hubbard. Grade: A+<br />Stiletto: This is one song that will make you snap your fingers to the beat. Joel's pulsating piano combined with an intense rhythm section gives this song a \\"West Side Story\\" feel to it. Far better than the somewhat sappy \\"She's Always A Woman\\". Grade: B+<br />Rosalinda's Eyes: Another favorite. Nice mix of Latin and jazz styles. Grade: A+<br />Half a Mile Away: Good up-tempo number that tells of Joel's urban world. The brass section is solid and makes this song move. Grade: B<br />Until the Night: This is one of the few songs on this album that I definitely don't like. \\"Until the Night\\" is a rather slow piece that lacks any real melody. It's also rather heavy and a bit pretentious. Grade: F<br />52nd Street: Richie Canatta's clarinet gives this song a New Orleans jazz flavor which is good because this is basically a bland song that doesn't have much to recommend it. Too bad Joel couldn't have ended this album on a better note. Grade: D-
B00005QG9J|5.0|I really don't understand what's wrong with Incubus changing up their style.  They carry enough talent and diversity to do so.  I must admit that &quot;Make Yourself&quot; is my alltime favorite Incubus album, but &quot;Morning View&quot; comes in a close second.  The melodies to the songs are infectious and contagious, the lyric is smart and thought-provoking, and the voice of lead-singer Brandon Boyd is irresistably sexy-- strong in the heavy songs and calm in the lighter songs.  What an amazingly talented band.  Anyone who has an open mind about change and buys this cd shouldn't be disappointed.

B000006TRV|1.0|Let's step back in time some 20 years...I was a Pink Floyd fan at that time. Loved &quot;Dark Side of the Moon&quot;, loved &quot;Wish You Were Here&quot;. Then comes The Wall, with &quot;Another Brick in the Wall&quot;. <br />&quot;We don't need no education...&quot; When I first heard that, those many years ago, I was completely enraged. Perhaps the Floyds were protesting the system in place at the time, but I survived it with my faculties intact and then and now enraged at the general level of ignorance in American society. Without education, we'd still be living at the cultural level of gorillas and chimpanzees. <br />Somewhere in the boxes unpacked since several moves ago are those original 33rpm LP records of &quot;Dark Side&quot; and &quot;Wish You Were Here&quot; ,and the cassette tapes I copied from them . B00005QDW5|3.0|If you're new to Floyd, or wish to explore beyond what you hear on the radio all the time, then this is a good place to start. It contains songs from all the major phases of the band, including the Syd Barrett era, the Roger Waters era, and the David Gilmour era. Most of the hits are here, including &quot;Money&quot;, &quot;Comfortably Numb&quot;, &quot;Wish You Were Here&quot;, and of course &quot;Another Brick In The Wall (Part II)&quot;.<br />However, as with most &quot;greatest hits&quot; albums, some of their best known works are not represented. &quot;Have A Cigar&quot;, &quot;Run Like Hell&quot;, and &quot;Welcome to the Machine&quot; are all missing, as is the classic &quot;Brain Damage&quot; (&quot;...I'll see you on the dark side of the moon...&quot;). Still, this is a much better compilation than &quot;A Collection of Great Dance Songs&quot; (which lacked any Syd Barrett material) or &quot;Works&quot; (which lacked most of the hits).<br />Now, if you're a die-hard Floyd fan, you might want to think twice before getting this one. For starters, there's probably nothing here that you don't already have, with the possible exception of &quot;When the Tigers Broke Free&quot; (previously unavailable on CD). Also, as stated above, many classics are omitted, including the essential instrumentals &quot;Interstellar Overderive&quot; and &quot;Careful With That Axe, Eugene&quot;. Also, it seems the band chose to ignore certain albums all together, as there are no songs from &quot;More&quot;, &quot;Ummagumma&quot;, &quot;Atom Heart Mother&quot;, or &quot;Obscured By Clouds&quot; on the album at all. And the classic track &quot;Echoes&quot; has been edited from its original 24 minute length to a much shorter version.<br />The ads for this album have been proclaiming that all the songs are mixed together to form one giant piece of music. This is not exactly the case. Like most Floyd records (Dark Side of the Moon for example), the songs simply fade into one another, andthere are no spaces in between the tracks. And the songs are not in chronological order, so a song like Gilmour's &quot;High Hopes&quot; fades into the Barrett classic &quot;Bike&quot;. This was probably done to make the Gilmour material seem just as strong and important as the Waters/Barret material, but it just makes for some jarring transisitions, as the Gilmour-era Floyd sounds so watered-down compared to the Floyd of old.<br />Bottom line? A good starting point for the curious or new fan, but not essential for die-hards.
0446677450|4.0|I think this book is a good way to establish the beginning skills necessary to reach for economic success. Robert T. Kiyosaki, in this book states that the basic skill necessary to be economically successful in life and to get out of what he calls the &quot;rat race&quot; is to become financially literate; to understand the difference between an asset and a liability and to understand cashflow. He refers to liabilities as things that take money out of your pocket and refers to assets as anything that puts money in your pocket. With these two concepts he builds the basic foundation for the reader to understand how the rich get rich and the poor remain poor. The rich, Kiyosaki states that save their money in assets and increase these assets by reducing their liabilities. He shows the reader how to make money work for them instead of working for money, and get out of the &quot;rat race&quot;. The one downside of this book is that he becomes repetitive, but its only to make the reader understand the importance of his words.

6304712944|4.0|A musical. But this is NOT a chick flick. This is an era of Hollywood stage-to-screen musicals at it's best. You all know the myth of Arthur, Guinever, and Lancelot in so many permeated forms. This is the one that started it all, and if I must say (oh, I must, I must), it is one of the best (maybe Excalibur). I read Maltin's review, and I gotta tell ya, Maltin needs to crack open a few cold ones and get off the high horse. Yes, Camelot can be a rather stiff translation from stage to screen at times, but take the whole bag or don't take it at all. Richard Harris made his mark with this movie. He is THE King Arthur which all subsequent Arthurs are guaged by. Venessa Redgrave never looked or acted better (I mean that), and the scene where Lancelot (Franco Nero) believed he had killed his friend in a joust, damn near made me cry. It was exceptional, considering this movie was done during the men-don't-cry era. David Hemmings is the perfect bastard as Mordred, Arthur's son by his sister. I don't know why Arthur insisted on calling Guinevere `Jenny', nor Lancelot `Lance'. I presume it was to `update' the film. But it doesn't matter. Every phrase is perfect in it's place. Arthur's solitary prose upon discovering Lancelot's love for Guinvere is a masterpiece in reflection, and it's style is still copied to this day. Something that makes you realize there was such great screenwriting in the 60's. There is a certain sadness in the movies' realization of a time and world lost, yet the songs, `What Do The Simple Folk Do', `Camelot', and `If I Ever Would Leave You' have created an eternal survival for this film. The costuming was typical `clean' serf suits, but the scenery looked as real as could be. And the soundtrack? absolutely magnificant. I am not a big fan of musicals. I am not a fan of overacting. But the background music to this film is as stirring as Armeggeddon, and the cinematography is excellent. There are no flaws in the film-to-dvd translation. If you own Lawrence of Arabia, you will own this. There is a line in this movie, &quot;you will learn that the world wags, and what wags it&quot;. There is magic in this film. It embraces that kind of enchantment. Trust me. I am never wrong.of Arabia, you will own this. There is a line in this movie, &quot;you will learn that the world wags, and what wags it&quot;. After viewing several bootleg videos from the 70's and 80's, it is awesome to see real camera work, hear clean sound and see Bruce at his best. He has not lost a thing. My TV is 32 inches, but if you are considering buying a surround sound system or a big screen TV - now is the time. B00005NI5Y|5.0|Every time Bob releases a new collection the entire world is eager to proclaim it his best since...Blood on the Tracks?  John Wesley Harding?  Blonde on Blonde?  Bringin' It All Back Home?  This type of grading system becomes awkward and ineffective when evaluating CLASSIC Dylan, as this most definitely is.  For all the positive press and critical acclaim Time Out of Mind gets, Love and Theft puts it to shame.  The closest thing to filler you'll find here is Bye and Bye, which is a little goofy and out of place here in my book.  What can I say about Mississippi?  The song I've been waiting for from Bob for years.  Reflective and strong, daring and brave.  For those who question Dylan's voice, I can recommend no better vehicle to demonstrate it's power than this.  Dylan's voice is not just an instrument.  It's a WEAPON.  No one else on the planet could capture the essence of this instant classic the way Bob does.  Thank you for that one, Bob.  There's diversity here as well.  Who else could create a mood and feeling the way Dylan does with Highwater, and then follow that up with Moonlight?  Summer Days is another highlight here.  The intracacies of Bob's phrasing are sharp and effective.  This collection is a must-have.  I speak as a lifelong fan of Dylan when I say this.  How will anyone else feel about Love and Theft?  I can't begin to imagine.  Who says you can't come back all the way?

0195067142|5.0|This book finally enabled me to fill in the story surrounding the tidbits of things my Dad reluctantly divulged about the brutal, muddy, bloody events he lived through as a Sergeant on Okinawa with what the Marines called their Army division, the 77th Infantry Division. Dad received a Silver Star (which, when you read the citation, you would swear is as much deserving of the Medal of Honor as a lot of those citations I have read), and, because his company was so decimated, had to have 2nd Lt. bars pinned on him on the battlefield.  He suffered all his life with various ailments traceable to living, eating, sleeping in the mud on Okinawa, never complaining or burdening other Americans to pay him disability, and died in 1981. Dad never lived to see his grandson, Kyle, have 2nd Lt. bars pinned on him at West Point. (Or did he?).

A bit monotonous at times but I just love how deep Iggy's voice gets on this song. It has a trip hop influence in the song, long before the term trip hop was defined. Sleeper's cover of the Blondie classic &quot;Atomic&quot; is excellent without a doubt. Catchy and darn right fun to listen to. I almost love this version more than the original and I love Blondie's music to death. I think my very personal favorite track off the soundtrack has to be New Order's &quot;Temptation&quot;. Elastica's &quot;2:1&quot; is awesome. That is probably my all time favorite Elastica song. It's short and sweet. The timing of the beats in the song and Justine Frischman's vocals is what blows my mind away. And of course there is Underworld's &quot;Born Slippy&quot;, the song that put this soundtrack on the map as well as for the band. That song and Leftfield's &quot;A Final Hit&quot; are just classic techno music. What I love most about this cd is how it eclectic it is and that the artists and bands put on the album are/were both established and new. You don't see established artists and new artists on the same album very often. The film industry should use the &quot;Trainspotting&quot; soundtrack as an architect to how soundtracks should be, as art and not another form of crass commercialism.
B00005OM4N|5.0|This is a great Cd - funky and original - very fun!
B000002C1W|5.0|15 years later people are still complaining about this cd. Let me tell you, the best thing that could have happened to pink floyd was to have roger waters leave. how long did he think he could exploit syd barrett's dimentia? The work they turned out with waters was fantastic and I loved it but &quot;The Final Cut&quot; proved that things were getting stale. The PF style is obvious on AMLOR but it's missing the oppressive, smothering self pity that Waters injected. This allows them to truly perform and improvise, not just mimic past works. No where in the PF chronicles does anything like &quot;Terminal Frost&quot; appear. Listening to Gilmour trade licks with Tom Scott's sax is a musical feast -- a simplistic tune performed by the musical elite. How about &quot;One Slip&quot; or &quot;Yet Another Movie&quot;? Is there a PF type message there? Well, you have to put down your bong and pay attention but yes there is. I love this cd. I've had to replace it twice because I wore it out but that's the mark of a great work, after 15 years people are still talking about it.
B0000047CW|5.0|How do you critique the album that started an era? Forty years later, Jazz Samba is still one of the most relaxing, rhythmically pleasing albums made. All instrumental, with the tenor sax of Stan Getz (the guy John Coltrane professed to admire!) and inspired guitar of Charlie Byrd. The entire album was recorded in one session in the performance hall of a Washington, D.C., church, and it puts legions of studio albums to shame.<br />While Desafinado and Bahia are the best known tracks, the album is a seamless experience and it is difficult to single out certain songs as superior. If Getz is one of the masters of the tenor saxophone, it is also hard to separate his proficiency from the effort as a whole -- it truly comes across as a tight ensemble effort. (For a contrast, Duke Ellington's masterful and equally essential Money Jungle released the same year finds the trio of Ellington, Mingus and Max Roach locked in a musical duel on a couple of tracks.)<br />Favorites? I enjoy Samba de Uma Nota So, but every time I reach for Jazz Samba I alway listen to the entire album. At least once. This and Getz/Gilberto belong in every jazz collection.
0790749815|5.0|I was fortunate to have studied this movie in detail during a college film class, and 20 years later, it remains my favorite all time Alfred Hitchcock flick (and the master justifies many of my favorites over time.)  Very few films are able to retain the one-two punch of being classics within a genre and remain remarkably fresh, accessible and fun (yes, even fun!)  Cary Grant is amazing throughout as the executive mistaken for someone else by both criminals and the authorities.  Few of his contemporaries (or even actors since Grant's glory days) ever mastered the dual qualities of being both manly and approachable which Grant offers in spades.  He is the everyday simple man, on the order of a James Stewart, and yet, a leading man matinee idol that has charmed viewers for decades.  He lures you with his affect, but never in a way that feels tired or condescending, always with good nature and a crooked eyebrow that knows more about life than most full fledged characters ever placed on screen.<br />The movie moves from New York through the Heartland, to fields of corn, to a climax that is visually and emotionally stunning.  The supporting characters all lend crediblity to the zig zag tale that rarely allows the viewer to catch his or her breath.  Eva Marie Saint and James Mason are especially delicious, and the viewer is forced repeatedly to question whether they are good guys, bad guys or neither, which only adds to the fun.  <br />Great actors and filmmaking aside, what makes &quot;North By Northwest&quot; especially important in today's world are its still-vital themes and how these relate to the ever-changing world we live in.  Cases of mistaken identity are more present now than before, as Muslims and Arab Americans confront the spectacle of being reduced to second class citizens despite their long, proud history and embrace of American values, and the American Dream itself.  Grant's character is literally hounded by both good and evil, but retains intact his inner virtues, and knows deep inside where he stands, like our Muslim and Arab countrymen, and most of the world's human population.  <br />In addition, Grant's &quot;everyman&quot; could be any one of us which adds to the suspense and allows us to feel a bond with this character that is rare among Hitchcock leads.  In fact, Hitchcock seems to have originated &quot;racial profiling&quot; here - albeit for the omnipresent &quot;white man.&quot;  If you think about it, mistaken identities are often the driving force behind racial profiling and the Master truly drives this point home.  Again, knowing this only makes the film more impoactful and adds to its universality today.<br />Finally, in an era of bioterrorism and unprecendented disasters like the attacks on the World Trade Centers of 9-11, &quot;North by Northwest&quot; seems more contemporary now than even 30+ years ago.  The cropduster scene takes on new resonance given what we're witnessing at the moment with anthrax, and the days immediately following the terrorist events, when cropdusters and other small planes were forced to suspend operation.  <br />Plus, the events of September 11th appear supremely tied to what transpires at Mt Rushmore during near the end of the film.  Think about it - like the hijacker's destruction of the World Trade Center and the Pentagon, beloved icons for modern Americans, the Presidential busts carved into the side of the mountain as used in the film are literally extensions of our pride, patriotism, heritage and history.  They represent all that &quot;is good&quot; in America, and applaud the democracy that has led the world for centuries to new, unparalleled glories.  The evil characters in the film are foiled by the mountain, and the all-American Grant endures (as shall we.)  While a mountain can't implode like the Towers themselves, the ground around them can be desacrated by murderers, and Hitchcock foreshadows the tragedies of 9-11 with uncanny vision.  The four Presidents on the mountain seem to stare down at Grant and give him the power to go on, while at the same time toppling the assailants.  Like them, our 6 living Presidents, from Ford to Bush, have crossed party lines and formed unilateral, unprecedented loyalty in the fact of terror.  If only life were fiction like Hitchcock's tale, perhaps the themes he presents would not be as terrifyingly real as they actually feel at this fateful moment in time!  I hate to read into this, but Hitchcock speaks volumes in this film about the nature of our culture, the values that sustain and inspire us, as well as the forces that would prefer to see us destroyed.  <br />On DVD, &quot;North by Northwest&quot;, reaffirms its status as the Master's truest work of art and renews his position as the greatest filmmaker of his day.  You can escape with this movie, but realize that, more today than ever the film generates a passion and vision that is more real, more intense and far more frieghtening than ever before.  Justice prevails, as it always does, yet Hitchcock makes the viewer go through hell first!  Just like the world's civilized nations are coping with terror  today, so does the Grant character.  A joyous, supreme example of filmmaking that is unparalleled both in its cinematic achievment as well as its topicality.

B00005QDW5|4.0|Nick Mason, David Gilmour, Roger Waters, Syd Barrett, and Richard Wright did the world great service by deciding to become professional musicians. Since the 1960s, Pink Floyd has been one of the greatest, most innovative music groups of recent memory. An almot infinite number of positive adjectives can be said of their music; however, words are essentially meaningless when it comes to trying to capture a sense of their music's beauty. <br />If music has any greatness, any long-lasting impact, and if it genuinely solicits your emotions, it has to be heard to be truly felt and understood. This applies as well to the music of Beethoven as it does to this consistently amazing band. For anyone who has just discovered Pink Floyd, this album is highly recommended as a \\"primer\\". It showcases the band's evolution, from its wild earlier days with vocalist Syd Barrett, to its more familiar sound with the addition of bassist/vocalist/lyricist Roger Waters. After Waters' rift with David Gilmour, the band continued to create wonderful music, which it is by now cliche to be referred to as \\"atmospheric.\\" <br />This compilation is no mere greatest hits strung together carelessly by the royalty-holders in an effort to grab that cash with both hands and make a stash. The tracks have been selected with care, seamlessly edited together, and ordered in such a way that you can draw connections between their earlier and later works. My one qualm is that my favourite song, \\"Echoes\\", was surgically truncated in five or six places; as the song was originally 23 minutes long, I'm not surprised. So, if you don't have the complete albums from which the tracks are culled, buy this NOW dammit!<br />Being 21 in a time when music produced by and for those my age group is more boring and lifeless than a church sermon is quie sad. I get the feeling that any given period of time can only have so many great artistic geniuses. We'll have to wait a while for another Stanley Kubrick, or Pablo Picasso, or Pink Floyd to come along and re-invigorate our tiny yet sweet little lives. Until then, shine on you crazy diamonds....

B00003CXA4|5.0|&#34;Gandhi&#34; is a brilliant encapsulation of the life of the man who must be counted among the greatest, most admirable figures in the history of humankind.  Starring Ben Kingsley, Martin Sheen, Candice Bergen, Rohini Hattangady, Roshan Seth, John Gielgud, and Trevor Howard, and directed by Richard Attenborough, this 1982 film is a stunning achievement - without doubt one of the finest biographical epics ever made.  It garnered six Academy Awards, including Best Picture; Best Actor (Kingsley); and Best Director (Attenborough).  This film beautifully fulfills the goals set out in the film's preface: &#34;...to be faithful in spirit to the record and try to find one's way to the heart of the man...&#34;<br /><br />As this film demonstrates, Mohandas K. Gandhi, always faithful to his principles of equality, justice, and peace, uses non-violent civil disobedience as a means to gain equality for his nation's oppressed.  his weapon. He is repeatedly assaulted by police and is imprisoned - usually on trumped up charges - several times because of his political beliefs and activism. Yet this always gentle and humble gentle man never loses sight of his main goal: helping his people achieve political and economic equality.  Although only marginally successful, Gandhi becomes famous throughout the world for his work in South Africa and India.<br /><br />In this masterfully produced, directed, written, and acted film, the life of Mohandas K. Gandhi is painted against the backdrop of some of the most momentous events in twentieth century Indian history.  &#34;Gandhi&#34; shows how the Mahatma (Great Soul) leads a nation of 350 million people to freedom from British colonial rule using non-violent means.<br /><br />We see Gandhi at the outset, making speeches in his low-key style, but even then espousing his clearly defined doctrine of peaceful non-cooperation against a repressive British colonial rule.  Contrary to many public perceptions of the man, this film shows that Gandhi was not just a simple, humble man in a loincloth.  He was a shrewd, pragmatic man who knew the value of good press in the furtherance of his cause.  He knew how to confront his political enemies in ways that got his point across while garnering from his foes a grudging respect.<br /><br />Throughout all these tumultuous events, Gandhi never wavers from his belief in non-violent civil resistance as a means of achieving justice, equality, and freedom for the Indian nation.<br /><br />January 30, 1948: a supreme irony:  Mohandas K. Gandhi - the man of peace who consistently espouses the dignity of all people; the proponent of non-violence, equality, justice, and peace - is violently gunned down by an assassin working for a fanatic Hindu group.<br />There are simply not enough  superlatives to do adequate justice to &#34;Gandhi.&#34;  Every aspect of this film is masterfully done!<br /><br />Ben Kingsley's portrayal of Gandhi is one of those singular performances that is so good that it defies description.  His meticulous preparation for this part is readily evident in every scene in which he appears.  His physical resemblance to the real Gandhi,  and the way he mimicked Gandhi's mannerisms, is so realistic as to be positively eerie.  Kingsley's performance is always sensitive, even slightly understated.  Yet there is always present a powerful intensity that conveys the deep spirituality and integrity of the man he so lovingly portrays.<br /><br />Other performances, although nowhere near as wide-ranging, are no less outstanding.  Among them:  John Gielgud as the slighly addled, pompous British viceroy, Lord Irwin; Trevor Howard as the British judge whose respect for defendant Gandhi leads him to rise from his seat in deference to the man he is about to sentence to prison; Roshan Seth as Pandit Jawaharlal Nehru, the staunchly loyal disciple and future Indian Prime Minister; and  Rohini Hattangady as Gandhi's loving wife.<br /><br />A NOTE ABOUT THE DVD:  &#34;Gandhi,&#34; a 20-year old film, was only released on DVD for the first time in October 2001.  This a truly magnificent restoration and remastering of this great film! It's the first time that &#34;Gandhi&#34; appears on recorded media in its original 2.35:1 widescreen format.  Video and audio quality are both simply outstanding!  There are plenty of &#34;extras&#34; included on the DVD, including a &#34;Making of Gandhi&#34; photo montage and several newsreel clips showing Gandhi at several important points in his life.<br /><br />&#34;Gandhi&#34; is a film that belongs in every movie lover's DVD collection&#34; a 20-year old film, was only released on DVD for the first time in October 2001.  This a truly magnificent restoration and remastering of this great film! It's the first time that &#34;Gandhi&#34; appears on recorded media in its original 2.35:1 widescreen format.  Video and audio quality are both simply outstanding!  There are plenty of &#34;extras&#34; included on the DVD, including a &#34;Making of Gandhi&#34; photo montage and several newsreel clips showing Gandhi at several important points in his life.<br /><br />&#34;Gandhi&#34; is a film that belongs in every movie lover's DVD collection

0812550757|5.0|I have always thought it a little ironic that both &quot;Ender's Game&quot; and &quot;Speaker&quot; both recieved the Hugo and Nebula Awards. To my mind, the only connection they have with science fiction is the fact that they take place in a time when interstellar travel is prevalent. The purpose of science fiction is to get people excited about the future of technology: to revive in our culture the scientific optimism that got us to the Moon. Neither of these books -- and I discuss them as a unit, even though they are so different, with such different scope -- comes anywhere close to that. &quot;Speaker&quot; especially, is a work that asks much deeper quesions about human nature than science can answer satisfactorily.<br />&quot;Speaker For The Dead&quot; is my candidate for Greatest Fiction Work of the Twentieth Century. I do not say this lightly, even though I have not read all of the fiction, even that labeled &quot;great literary fiction,&quot; that literary critics have canonized. &quot;Speaker&quot; transcends literary genres and prototypes. I doubt whether science fiction has ever been used to pose so many eternal questions. It is not simply a great novel: it is a work of philosophy couched in a story. This book may be fictional, but it is True! The events of Speaker may never actually happen, but the world Card has painted for us is no longer a painting, but has sprung up into a full-scale universe.<br />It is too bad that Card could not have limited himself to &quot;Speaker,&quot; instead of forcing himself to draw out the story into &quot;Xenocide,&quot; and then &quot;Children of the Mind.&quot; Neither of those two lives up to &quot;Speaker&quot;'s elegant simplicity and unavoidable probing questioning into the heart of every reader. These two are science fiction -- their worlds eminently don't work, and I'm not talking about the physics. His characters become stylized, form fitted; he is shaping the plot to find an ending, and finds he has to extend and distend it to make that ending satisfactory. I have a similar criticism of &quot;Ender's Shadow&quot; and &quot;Shadow of the Hegemon&quot;: they do not ask the profound questions that &quot;Ender's Game&quot; did; they stay on the plane of events.and distend it to make that ending satisfactory. I have a similar criticism of &quot;Ender's Shadow&quot; and &quot;Shadow of the Hegemon&quot;: they do not ask the profound questions that &quot;Ender's Game&quot; did; they stay on the plane of events.

B00005QDW5|3.0|An acceptable attempt at achieving the impossible. On the plus side, the inclusion of 5 Barrett tracks is commendable. And most of Floyd's classics are well represented. As for the downside, &quot;Apples and Oranges&quot; (1967) should have been included, not to mention the unreleased &quot;Vegetable Man&quot; and &quot;Scream Thy Last Scream.&quot; What happened to 1969 and 1970? And many of the segues, though tolerable, are less than perfect. But the biggest complaint I have is with the edited version of &quot;Echoes.&quot; Firstly, the sound doesn't seem psychedelic enough. I have a Japanese import of Meddle on vinyl that renders this CD version of &quot;Echoes&quot; sonically inferior. Furthermore, disc 1 clocks in at over 76 minutes, so why did they chop out over 7 minutes of this masterpiece when they still had over 3 minutes to play with? They not only chopped out passages from the intro and extended 'noise' sections; they also removed key parts of the buildup prior to the 'funky' jam and portions of the 'funky' jam itself. One of These Days I'm Going To Cut You Into Little Pieces!

B00003CXTG|1.0|I tried hard to find something to like about this movie, but other than Hans Zimmer's film score (and even that was substandard compared to his other works), this movie was a massive disappointment.  <br />Based on the bad reviews, I went in with low expectations and Michael Bay failed to meet even those.  Although Ben Affleck and Kate Beckinsale tried hard with a bad script, aside from their efforts the acting was cardboard, the dialogue was shallow, the love-story plot was predictable and unoriginal, the special effects were WAY overpriced (prop planes don't fly like X-wing fighters), and the history-well, from end to end the movie was replete with historical errors, from mundane stuff (e.g., incorrect uniforms, wrongly painted aircraft) to more serious errors (e.g., Doolittle Raid bombers flying in formation, at altitude, with fighter pilots at the controls, providing running commentary on the radio, etc. etc. etc.)  By themselves, each of the errors is insignificant, but taken together, they give the lie to Bay's claim that this would be the most historically accurate film possible.  They also raise the question:  if you're going to spend this much money to make a movie, isn't worthwhile to get your facts straight (especially when you don't have to be a history professor to get them)?  <br />About the only good thing I can say about this moive is that if it helps to instill some appreciation of our country's history in people who didn't have that appreciation before, then it will have served a good purpose.  But if you want an accurate historical portrayal of Pearl Harbor (using real aircraft as opposed to unrealistic pretenders), you're not going to do better than \\"Tora, Tora, Tora.\\"  If you want a quality love story set against the backdrop of the Pearl Harbor attack, you can't beat \\"From Here to Eternity.\\"  As far as this one goes, save your money.  I wish I had.

McCourt believes that people in America who are as poor as he is live like the wealthy people in Limerick. McCourt tells everyone in the novel that he will never again live like they do in Irland.This proves to the audience that his dream is to return to America and not live like those in his town. <BR> Another thing that really makes Angelas Ashes is the tragedy that Frank McCourt and his family over came, by lossing 3 kids to illness and their father to the drink. This gave me so much hope even though he McCourt had suffered so greatly it was so apairent that if he had not he would not have become what he became, and that is such an influencial leader and author. As opposed to not telling much about all his charcters except for himself McCourt gave indepth discriptions about each one of their personalities. Including his two dead brothers and one dead sister. He would spend pages explaining the looks in their eyes that led the reader to know much more about them.<BR>This is truly a great book that though has much sorrow also has a great message, and gives people hope in the common man. McCourt is truly very strong and has helped so many people understand the effects of a lack of father and overcoming extream tragedy. B00005OM4N|2.0|Britney's self-titled third album has been hyped by the media as one that expresses the older, more mature Britney.  Britney herself has proclaimed on MTV that she wrote almost every song on the album, when in fact she CO-WROTE only 5 of the album's 12 tracks.  So, does this album show Britney's growth from pop princess to mature songstress?  Let's just say she still has some work to do.<br />&quot;Britney&quot; is not a horrible album, but it will leave many of her die hard fans disappointed, especially those in their early adolescence.  Gone are the catchy, melodic tracks with infectious choruses like &quot;...Baby One More Time&quot;, &quot;Oops!...I Did It Again&quot;, &quot;Sometimes&quot;, and &quot;Stronger&quot;.  The first single is a clear indication of this.  &quot;I'm A Slave 4 U&quot; is perhaps the worst song on the album.  Why it was chosen to be the album's first single is a mystery.  Fortunately, this wasn't one of the Britney penned tunes.  The Neptunes are to blame for this bland, uninspiring track.<br />Fortunately, Britney was smart enough to continue to work with Max Martin on this album.  His catchy tunes from Britney's first two albums made her what she is today.  In fact, the only truly melodic songs on the album are those that were co-written by Martin.  These include &quot;Overprotected&quot;, &quot;I'm Not A Girl, Not Yet A Woman&quot;, and &quot;Cinderella&quot;.  I'd like to say that the other Martin song, &quot;Bombastic Love&quot;, is melodic as well, but it sounds like such a blatant rip-off of Britney's Pepsi commercial jingle that I just can't take it seriously.  The other three are certainly single material, though none can compete with the catchy singles from Britney's first two albums.  <br />Th rest of the album sounds like nothing more than filler material, which is pretty pathetic considering the entire 12 track album isn't quite 40 minutes in length.  Even Britney's cover of &quot;I Love Rock 'n' Roll&quot; sounds almost silly.  Talk about butchering a classic.  Britney may be gorgeous, but she can't belt out a hard rock anthem like Joan Jett.<br />The bottom line is that, if you're a hard core Britney fan, you're going to buy this album regardless of how many people tell you it's a disappointment.  However, if you're a fan of Britney's catchy, sing-along pop tunes, you are in for a major let-down.  While it's admirable for Britney to want to mature as a singer and express herself by writing her own songs, she could've done much better than this.  No matter how personal a song is to you, if it doesn't sound good to the listener it isn't worth putting it on an album.  As a Britney fan, I expected a lot more than I got.  Maybe my expectations were too high, but after two great pop albums I was hoping for some more classic melodies.  With a lack of truly standout single material and songs that won't be appealing to the millions of young fans who made Britney a superstar, it would be a miracle if this album were to come close to the successes of her previous two.  Still, Britney remains a great singer and dancer, and hopefully this will just be a forgettable album in a long and successful career for this young talent.

0316776963|4.0|Sedaris manages to give us both a laugh-out-loud read and a wonderful portrait of a man and the way he relates to his world.  His characters are vivid (in particular his siblings, the Rooster and Amy). His stories are typically self deprecating with a hint of regret or sadness.  But he manages to keep it light, leaving you laughing the whole time.  The myriad of essay subjects manages to portray so many aspects of one person's life.<br />Since reading the book, everyone I run into who has already read it and I have spent time retelling the stories Sedaris tells.  This will not be the most intellectually challenging or deep book you read this year, but it might be the most fun!

B00005OM4N|4.0|Britney Spears, there has been so much written and said about the 19 year old pop star in the past couple of years that one would almost forget that she's a singer. Well more of an entertainer, that moniker would fit Britney a little better since she doesn't have the vocal range of counterpart Christina Aguilera. But Britney definently works with what she has. Sexy, stylized dance moves and hook filled pop ditties that don't require much from vocal chords but more from an image driven sex kitten (i.e. J.Lo &amp; Janet). Britney definently brings to mind predecessor Madonna, who used her sex appeal and hot tunes to claw her way to the top. Britney's 3rd album, &quot;BRITNEY&quot; is an excellent example of an artist wanting to outgrow an image and if the public won't allow the change gradually then the artist decides to force the issue. Britney sings a lot on this album about &quot;not being a little girl&quot; and wanting to feel sexy and doing what she does best....dance. With only 1 ballad track on the disc, Britney seems more determined than ever to carve her niche as a dance diva. This album does manage to have some good, stand alone tracks, like the dance club/top 40 radio ready &quot;Anticipating&quot; which borrows heavily from Janet Jackson's &quot;All For You&quot; except Britney's track seems lighter, less funky but just as danceable. &quot;I'm A Slave 4 U&quot;, the 1st single released from BRITNEY is funk personnified, with Britney declaring &quot;just let me go and listen&quot;. Britney co-wrote several songs on the album and even though her material seems a bit cheesy, she's not expected to be Diane Warren or even Mariah Carey on her first time at bat. Some songs on the disc however do have the distinction of being solely album filler, like &quot;Bombastic Love&quot; and &quot;Boys&quot; which come off as being leftovers from previous recording sessions. And as she did previously with &quot;Can't Get No (Satisfaction)&quot;, Britney has churned out another horrid remake of a rock classic in &quot;I Love Rock &amp; Roll&quot;, Britney please give up this desire to redo beloved rock anthems into bubblegum rehashes for the Y generation, it doesn't become you. With &quot;I'm Not A Girl, Not Yet A Woman&quot; Britney again attempts to drive home her point of growing up but with the song being Britney's first AC radio ready ballad, it definently serves it purpose but theres no defining quality about the song which could have possibly fit the bill as Spears' signature song it might as well have been sung by Mandy Moore or Jessica Simpson.  But all in all Britney definently is showing growth as an artist, she is finally showing that maybe she's not a producer's puppet and with more fine tuning and time she'll progress into a solid pop artist just like her mentor Madonna.
0385505833|5.0|John Grisham exits nicely from the world of lawyers, courtrooms, and sleeze and takes us into a world all of us would recognize: What would happen if we passed on Christmas this year?<br />Protagonist Luther Krank (okay, the name is a bit to revealing), an accountant who knows the cost of Christmas but not its value, calculates an alternative to Christmas parties, unwanted gifts, illuminated Frosty's, and more. Why not simply say &quot;no&quot; to Christmas? &quot;No&quot; to the neighbors decorating their homes, to the Boy Scouts selling trees, to the policeman selling calendars, to medics selling fruitcakes...just say &quot;no&quot; to everyone and everything concerning Christmas. Take all that money you spend on mindless cards, trinkets, and parties and spend it on something half the cost and much less stressful, like a cruise. Perhaps the only sentiment stronger than the tempatation to pass on the anxiety, crass commercialism, drunken office parties and competitive neighborhood decorations must be the nostalgia we all have for Bing Crosby White Christmas past. The Kranks fight hard to stay the course.<br />A slim, fast read, it would be a shame to deter the prospective reader by revealing the plot twist but it is transparent and predictable. But it's also fun, and heartwarming. A nice Christmas gift.

B000002R48|5.0|I was into Dream Theater from their very first release -- When Dream and Day Unite -- because of a review I'd read in Britain's Kerrang! magazine.<br />Being a major progressive and melodic rock freak, I just had to seek out this album and listen to it.<br />I did. And I did. And it hooked me from the start.<br />I have a confession to make, however. I've tried and tried and tried to like James LaBrie's vocals and I just can't. LaBrie alternates between a melodramatic breathiness and a where's-the-note-I'm-looking-for histrionic that grates on my nerves. That's why, for my tastes, this debut featuring Charlie Dominici is the perfect blend of superb musicianship and soaring vocals.<br />That's why even though I've seen Dream Theater in concert a half dozen times and have all of their albums, I return again and again to this debut -- especially when I'm at the office, where I do most of my listening. It's the perfect blend of pleasant, yet powerful vocals and a level of musicianship that astounds to this day.<br />Granted, the guitar work is a bit pushed back in the mix. And it seems slanted more toward the keyboards than it could have been. But each song is great. Very upbeat and driving. Particularly the last track, \\"Only a Matter of Time.\\" I put that on Repeat on my CD player at the office and use it to inspire my copywriting.<br />Other stand-out tracks include the now-classic \\"Ytse Jam\\" and \\"Light Fuse and Get Away.\\"<br />DT has come a long way since this debut release. They've literally become a world-wide phenomenon, revered by fans and critics alike. And held in highest regard by fellow musicians who consider them to be demi-gods. (Drummer Mike Portnoy has become one of today's most lauded musicians, appearing in not one but two noteworthy side projects: Liquid Tension Experiment and TransAtlantic. Both highly recommended.)<br />Even though they're superstars now, with a string of incredible albums under their belts, I'll always return to When Dream and Day Unite for the sheer enjoyment of hearing a band that started with a bang -- and just kept getting better.

B00005OM4N|3.0|First impression: with this third cd Britney finally changed direction a bit and went for a slightly more grown up sound/image. Conclusion: if you're not a Britney fan don't buy the album, you'll hate it. If you are a fan you'll be happy to hear that she's progressed since the last two albums. The majority of the tracks are still dance tracks, but edgier, raunchier even, though never exaggerated. If she could now just loose the kiddie dance songs from the Swedish duo and work a bit more on the ballads, she might be on her way to become the Madonna of the 21st century.
B00005OM4N|5.0|Our little Britney is growing up.  She's getting older, wiser, better looking... and in keeping with the old adage, &quot;the third time is a charm&quot;, Ms. Spears has delivered an album without a single solitary weak filler track on it. <br />Her first two albums, ...Baby One More Time and Oops!... I Did It Again, guilty pleasures that they were, had their fair share of filler (could the most diehard devoted Britney mark ever bear to listen to &quot;E-Mail My Heart&quot; all the way through again?) and some rather savage manglings of cover material (like the version of the Stones' &quot;Satisfaction&quot; that made Rage Against The Machine's bass player climb the walls at last year's MTV Video Awards, and the cover of Sonny &amp; Cher's &quot;The Beat Goes On&quot; that closed her first album). <br />Gone are those days.  Gone are most of the composers and producers on her first two albums, save for the redoubtable Max Martin &amp; Remi (the Swedish duo responsible for most of her singles) and R&amp;B heavyweight Rodney Jenkins (even though he produced Brit's cover of &quot;Satisfaction&quot;).  Helping Britney on her quest to not screw around in the studio making halfhearted filler tracks are hip-hop producer/multi-instrumental team The Neptunes, and the team of Brian Kieruff &amp; Josh Schwartz, who make a more prominent contribution to Britney not as producers, but as her songwriting collaborators.  Yes, collaborators - inspired by her boyfriend Justin Timberlake (of *NSync, who chips in a songwriting and producing contribution of his own with partner Wade Robson), and having warmed up her own pen with a track on Oops!..., our little Britney co-wrote five of the album's twelve tracks. <br />Gone is the sugary pop that once suited the young virginal, never been kissed Britney.  Instead, young adult Britney puts on her best husky alto for the TLC-esque &quot;Boys&quot; and the Prince-influenced &quot;I'm A Slave 4 U&quot;, brings in funk legend Nile Rodgers to contribute his classic guitar stylings to the disco/soul-meets-Daft Punk &quot;Anticipating&quot;, and delivers a remake of Joan Jett's &quot;I Love Rock 'N' Roll&quot; that pretty much erases the sour aftertaste &quot;Satisfaction&quot; left in people's mouths last year.   Other tracks like &quot;Overprotected&quot;, &quot;Cinderella&quot; and &quot;Bombastic Love&quot;, while initially recalling earlier Britney classics like &quot;(You Drive Me) Crazy&quot; and &quot;Stronger&quot;, reinforce Britney's current maturity rather than drag her back into the past. <br />If &quot;I'm A Slave 4 U&quot; is only one part of Britney's new mission statement, &quot;I'm Not A Girl, Not Yet A Woman&quot; is the other.  The only actual ballad on the entire album and a song co-written by Dido (yes, that Dido, as in &quot;Thank You&quot; and &quot;Stan&quot;), &quot;I'm Not A Girl...&quot; perfectly reflects the current milestone the 19-year-old singer is currently at. <br />If her music was a closet favorite of yours before, Britney will bring you out of the closet.  If you were already an unashamed fan of hers, you'll no doubt remain a fan of hers for life. Either way, this disc will probably find its way into your stereo more than her first two albums did. <br />Britney Spears has made no secret of her admiration of Madonna, and her desire to have a career as durable and memorable as the Material Girl's.  Britney, the album, may just be the album that helps Ms. Spears. on that journey, and if she keeps putting out material as good as what's on this release, she won't have any problem achieving that goal.
0553577123|5.0|Anne Frank may well have become a successful author had her life not been cut tragically short.  She is remarkably clear and effective in communicating an emotional sense of what it was like, at least from her point of view, to live an extended period in a severely restrictive environment.  Anne's optimism and faith rings clear without being expressly stated.  It is refreshing in that there is no hint of contrived drama or melodrama in her descriptions of everyday life suffused with internal and external stresses.  This book reads as honest, direct and true as life gets.<br />This book is the literal diary of a Jewish teen hiding from the Nazis in Holland during World War Two.  It covers the period in Anne's life from about thirteen to fifteen years old.  She lives on the top floor of a warehouse with her immediate family (mother, father, and sister) as well as another family of three (the &quot;Van Daan's&quot; and their sixteen year old son) and an older dentist with whom she must share a room.  The antics, conflicts and daily travails amidst food shortages, break-ins and a seemingly endless parade of small crises test the limits of the residents of the annex.  One of the more revealing episodes involves a brief fling at romance with the sixteen-year-old son of the Van Daan's and Anne.  It is a revealing look at adolescence and the process of maturity through a tightly focused lens. It is truly wrenching as you learn the fate of each of the residents.  One is left with an unforgettable snapshot of humanity, its courage and its failings, in a time of deep crisis and almost unbelievable tragedy.<br />The Diary of Anne Frank is often taught at the middle school level.  My sixth grade students expressed interest in the book, so I let them read as part of their reading curriculum.  I found that while most had little trouble understanding the book (they were above average readers) they were too young to really grasp and appreciate the subtle, and sometimes not so subtle themes running through the book.  They had no emotional sense of what these people's daily lives were like.  There was nothing in their limited life experience to help them appreciate or understand what living in such conditions for an extended period would be like.  Anne Frank would be better read at the high school level, or better yet, as a book read by choice.<br />A note on this edition:  The Definitive edition includes much material that was excised from the original diary.  Many of Anne's comments about her mother were less than flattering, and so her father (the only survivor in the book) sought to protect the memory of his wife.  This is certainly understandable, but the Definitive edition more honestly reflects Anne's feelings at the time.  I don't think there's too many people that would begrudge a teenager's rejection of their parents.  It's only sad that she didn't live long enough to come through and see her mom through the eyes of an adult.themes running through the book.  They had no emotional sense of what these people's daily lives were like.  There was nothing in their limited life experience to help them appreciate or understand what living in such conditions for an extended period would be like.  Anne Frank would be better read at the high school level, or better yet, as a book read by choice.<br />A note on this edition:  The Definitive edition includes much material that was excised from the original diary.  Many of Anne's comments about her mother were less than flattering, and so her father (the only survivor in the book) sought to protect the memory of his wife.  This is certainly understandable, but the Definitive edition more honestly reflects Anne's feelings at the time.  I don't think there's too many people that would begrudge a teenager's rejection of their parents.  It's only sad that she didn't live long enough to come through and see her mom through the eyes of an adult.
B00005QDW5|3.0|Throughout its thirty year career, Pink Floyd was a band marred by conflict among its members over differences in creative vision. No less then three &quot;incarnations&quot; of Pink Floyd have existed, in effect three different bands each lead by one dominating personality. Given the amount of creative variance the band experienced from year to year, and indeed from album to album, one has to question the validity of a &quot;Best of&quot; album - other than, in Waters' words, &quot;to scrape the bottom of the barrel for more dollar bills.&quot; Is it possible to capture the spirit of Pink Floyd with one compilation?<BR>Well, yes and no. The most successful albums Floyd has released in its career were concept albums (an album in which the music is centered around a unifying theme, for those of you born in the Britney generation). Thus, they are best appreciated as a whole, and in fact individual songs are less enjoyed and even understood when listened to out of context. Listeners who are not familiar with the Orwellian theme of &quot;Animals&quot; will likely find &quot;Sheep&quot; a little confusing, for example. Songs like &quot;The Fletcher Memorial Home&quot; from 1983's &quot;The Final Cut&quot; will make even less sense. Worse still, a whopping 4 albums are ignored completely - &quot;More&quot;, &quot;Ummugumma&quot;, &quot;Atom Heart Mother&quot;, and &quot;Obscured by Clouds&quot; all of which were recorded during the band's progressive rock experimentation phase. Moreover, the songs themselves are presented in more or less random order, which prevents the new listener from hearing the creative evolution of the band, from it's genesis as a psychedelic pop band, to it's death as a soft rock dinosaur. Instead, tracks are criminally intertwined without regard to the fact that, in some cases, they were written 25 years apart. In the end, listeners will no doubt be left wondering: which one's Pink?<BR>It's unfortunate that fans continue to be fed this kind of nostalgic tripe when so much more Pink Floyd material exists out there - notably, Floyd's BBC Sessions, unreleased film scores, and rare live recordings. Still, this reviewer hopes that &quot;Echoes&quot; may bring new fans to the fold, and in turn lend them a deeper appreciation of this outstanding band.

0553296981|5.0|Anne Frank: The Diary of a Young Girl is the autobiography of a young woman coming to terms with adolescence while hiding from the Nazis with other Jewish citizens throughout the early 1940s.  The novel is made up of the fascinating diary of the fourteen year-old (Anne Frank), and takes the reader on a journey through her deepest ideas and thoughts on the every-day trials and tribulations of life throughout a most painstakingly difficult period in the 20th Century.  Anne begins the story as a carefree schoolgirl and ends it as a wise and experienced young adult, giving the reader a sense of Annes remarkable character while living under the most fearfully uncomfortable conditions.<br />I have thoroughly enjoyed reading this book and after finishing it I have learned a lot about myself in the process.  This is because, in Annes continual fight with her own emotions and feelings, (and tiring struggle to stay true to herself), I began to challenge myself with questions about the strengths and weaknesses of my own character.  Since Anne's greatest quality is her awareness of her own self and her ability to know when she is being fair and when she being unreasonable, she also possesses the unique ability to reflect on these things with a profound sense of truth.  This admirable discipline of ones own conscience and clear, determined course of thought is something I wish I had, but I feel I have become more aware of this near the end of the book.<br />  (***)  Through analyzing Anne's entries to \\"Kitty\\" (Annes imaginary name of whom she writes to in her diary) I have become a little more compassionate and understanding, because I realize how important it is to be thankful for life.  So often I waste my time complaining about things, and little do I understand how well off I am in the big picture of the world.  Annes positive outlook and noble courage has inspired me to become more optimistic, and as an exceptionally bright 15 year-old she serves as a great role model for the youth of our generation.  I most definitely recommend this novel for mature teenage girls, it is most appropriate for 14 years of age and up.he youth of our generation.  I most definitely recommend this novel for mature teenage girls, it is most appropriate for 14 years of age and up.

0345413377|5.0|I am personally amazed to read some of the reviews of people saying how they did not enjoy this book. The Amber Spyglass is one of those rare books these days that you cannot put down. From the first page to the last it is filled with everything that readers of Philip Pullman's other two novels in this series have come to expect and enjoy, such as the sly way Mrs. Coulter always get things done(later in the book he shows a rather surprising and unexpected aspect of her personality), Lyra and her almost innocent and yet grown up way of looking at all she encounters, and Will and his strength to do what needs to be done. Other characters also make a return apperance such as the witch Serafina Pekkala, Lord Asriel, Iorek Brynison, Mary Malone, and perhaps a few that no one would expect to be able to make a return. <br />Pullman does make many world changes in this book, and introduces new characters, new creatures while further explaining both Lyra's and Will's destinies as well as those of everyone that they have encountered in a very pleasing and clean manner that should me very satisified. I was however saddened by the ending, perhaps in part because of part of what was required to make this ending as clean and a wonderful as it was and perhaps because it is the end of the series and the adventures of Will and Lyra have been cleanly ended within this novel. Overall it was a very excellent if not somewhat abrupt end to the series.  <br />What helps make The Amber Spyglass so special and unique are the challenges that Will and Lyra face throughout the book, including perhaps the hardest challenge they or anyone would ever have to face near the end. These challenges take many forms, and help the characters to explore more about both themselves and each other. They learn some of the secerts of the witches, and more both about Dust and Lord Asriel's 'war.' I can truly say that it is possible to see the very last choice that is almost forced on Will and Lyra to be sad forboth of them and yet in a way happy for seeing them make the difficult choice they have to make. <br />I have no hesitation in saying that in this book much as in the others it is the very challenges and the familiar topics, such as Dust, the Oblation Board, and the idea of the many worlds that are linked through the doorways that were shown to exist in The Subtle Knife, which help to make this book the  one that you cannot put down once you have started reading Chapter One. <br />Personally, I have only one regret about this book and that is the way in which it was ended leaves little chance for Pullman to take an chance and bring these characters back in another book. The ending does leave the option, but it is a small one. Overall I highly recommend this book and if you are unsure after reading some of the reviews that say otherwise about this book, I simply encourage you to read it and choose for yourself which type of book you believe it to be. Though personally I feel that you will find as I have Philip Pullman helps to make this as good as the The Golden Compass and The Subtle Knife, and perhaps the best in the His Dark Materials Series.
